Well, as X have said, these parties did participate at various
times in the governments headed by De Gasperl*But some of their members
always thought such a course politically unwise* At best they were only
tails to the Christian Democratic kite. Membership in a predominantly
Christian Democratic government seemed to involve these minor parties in
an obligation to defend that government. By belonging to such a govern¬
ment they risked being blamed for its shortcomings but found it difficult
to claim credit for its achievements. They were risking loss of their
political identities.
The Liberals finally dropped out in protest over the government1s
land reform program. The Social Democrats eventually dropped out because
of their belief that such a course would best promote party unity and win
defections from the left-wing Socialist party of Pietro Nennl. Only the
Republicans stuck with De Gasperl to the end.
But all three parties did establish an alliance with the Christian
Democrats for the June elections. And all three went along with the bigger
party in passing an ©lection law that aroused bitter opposition, not only
from the Communists, who branded it ”la legge truffa” — the swindle law —
but also many Italian democrats. It was this law that would have given any
party or group of parties getting one more than 50 per cent of the votes for
the Chamber of Deputies 64 per cent of the seats — or 380 seats out of the
590 total.
There is no doubt that this law was a big factor in the failure
of the Christian Democrats and their three allied parties to get that 50
per cent.
Their poor showings as minor partners of the Christian Democrats
caused the Social Democrats, Liberals and Republicans to have lengthy second
thoughts, not only on the electoral law but on the whole question of the
four-party coalition. And in any event, the election results were widely
regarded as a repudiation of that De Casperi coalition.
Giuseppe Saragat, leader of the Socall Democrats, looked at the
600,000 votes his party had lost and announced that he would come into the
new government only if the Nenni Socialists were also included. When
De Gasperl brushed this suggestion aside, for obvious reasons, Saragat
launched his policy of Mapertura a sinistra” — opening to the left. This
was designed either to effect reunion with Nenni's forces, on the condition
they would break their alliance with the Communists, or to win recruits from
Nenni if he refused to leave the Reds.
A split that had been brewing in Liberal ranks for a long time
threatened disaster. Historically, the Liberals have been a conservative
party, devoted to parliamentary democracy, but wary of government inter¬
ference with the established economic and social order.
But the left wing of the Liberal party, composed mostly of younger
men, now seems to be gaining the upper hand. Their economic and social
views are closely akin to those of the Republicans and the Saragat Socialists
The question now is whether this more progressive group can pre¬
vail without splitting the party. An indication of how nip and tuck the
intra-party battle is came recently at a meeting of the national council.
Bruno VilXabruna, supported by the left and center, was re-elected party
secretary, with 59 favorable votes. But 43 blank ballots were cast and 19
delegates abstained from voting.
